description.summary: A hybrid monster from Greek mythology with a lion's head and body, a goat's head growing from its back, and a serpent or dragon for a tail. Famous for breathing fire and being slain by the hero Bellerophon riding Pegasus.
description.full: The Chimera is a monstrous hybrid creature from Greek mythology, described as having the head and body of a lion, a second head of a goat protruding from its back, and a tail ending in a serpent's head or dragon. A fire-breathing female monster, the Chimera was the offspring of the giants Typhon and Echidna. She terrorized the region of Lycia until being slain by the hero Bellerophon, who rode the winged horse Pegasus. The Chimera has become the quintessential symbol of impossible hybrids and fantastical combinations, giving its name to the modern concept of 'chimera' - any impossible idea or hybrid creature. In genetics, chimerism refers to organisms containing cells with different DNA, named after this mythological beast.

history.modern_era: The Chimera has become the archetypal impossible hybrid. The term 'chimera' now means any fantastical or impossible idea, especially in science. In genetics, 'chimerism' describes organisms with cells from multiple DNA sources. The creature appears throughout fantasy literature, games, and art.

famous_myth.title: Bellerophon and the Chimera
famous_myth.summary: King Iobates of Lycia, at the urging of Proetus, sent the hero Bellerophon to slay the Chimera, expecting him to die. Bellerophon, with the help of the goddess Athena, tamed the winged horse Pegasus. Riding Pegasus, he attacked the Chimera from the air, avoiding its fire breath and ground attacks. He killed it by dropping lead into its mouth from above, which melted from the fire and choked the monster.
famous_myth.method: Some accounts say he used a lead-tipped spear or dropped lead into its mouth, which melted from the creature's fire

modern_usage: Scientific chimerism - organisms with multiple DNA sets
